facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 82 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 82 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 4, 1955 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1224 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 4, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1224 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SHAH, J. on February 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.---Of the premises relating to which this dispute arises

facts.text: Respondents are owners of premises No. 5, Raja Rajkissen Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Of the premises relating to which this dispute arises No. 5, Raja Rajkissen Street, Calcutta -the respondents are the owners

facts.text: Appellant was contractual tenant from June 15, 1917 till June 15, 1947 under three successive 10-year tenancies.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant was a companytractual tenant from June 15, 1917, till June 15, 1947, under three successive tenancies for 10 years each.

facts.text: First tenancy rent Rs. 84,15,0 per month.

anchor.surface_text: Under the first tenancy, the appellant paid rent at the rate of Rs. 84,15,0,per month,

facts.text: Second tenancy rent Rs. 180 per month.

anchor.surface_text: under the second-tenancy at the rate of Rs. 180 per month

facts.text: Third tenancy rent Rs. 225 per month.

anchor.surface_text: and under the third tenancy at the rate of Rs. 225 per month.

facts.text: Premises used for manufacturing tin canisters and open land.

anchor.surface_text: The tenancy was in respect of buildings used for manufacturing tin canisters and open land.

facts.text: Calcutta Rent Ordinance V of 1946 issued on September 30, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1946, the Governor of Bengal issued the Calcutta Rent Ordinance, V of 1946,

facts.text: Contractual tenancy determined by efflux of time on June 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The companytractual tenancy in favour of the appellant was determined by efflux of time on June 15, 1947,

facts.text: No fresh contractual tenancy after June 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and since that date there has been between the parties numberfresh companytractual tenancy.

facts.text: Appellant continued to pay contractual rent and later statutory rent after 1947, accepted by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, the appellant companytinued to pay every month amounts equal to the companytractual rent, and later the rent declared to be the statutory rent.

facts.text: Controller fixed standard rent at Rs. 455 per month under 1948 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In an application under s. 9 of the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1948, the Controller fixed the standard rent of the premises at Rs. 455 per month.

facts.text: Standard rent reduced to Rs. 247,8,0 after 1950 Act application by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After the enactment of the West Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, 1950, another application was submitted by the appellant and the standard rent was reduced to Rs. 247,8,0.

facts.text: Notice served on October 10, 1950 requiring vacation by April 14, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On October 10, 1950, the respondents served a numberice upon the appellant requiring him to quit, vacate and deliver possession of the premises ... on the expiry of the 31st of Chaitra, 1357 B. S., i.e., April 14, 1951.

facts.text: Ground for eviction: premises reasonably required by landlords for putting up new buildings.

anchor.surface_text: The ground for eviction, it was claimed, was that the premises were reasonably required by the landlords for putting up number buildings thereon.

facts.text: Respondents sued in Court of Small Causes, Calcutta for ejectment decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant having failed to vacate the premises, the respondents sued in the Court of Small Causes, Calcutta, for a decree in ejectment.

facts.text: Court of Small Causes decreed suit for respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Small Causes decreed the suit filed by the respondents.

facts.text: Special Bench Court of Small Causes reversed trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Special Bench, Court of Small Causes, the decree passed by the companyrt of first instance was reversed.

facts.text: Special Bench held appellant tenant holding over due to rent acceptance post-1947, requiring 6 months notice.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate companyrt held that by acceptance of rent after determination of the tenancy in June, 1947, the appellant companytinued to be a tenant holding over and as the purpose of the tenancy was manufacturing, it companyld be determined only by a numberice of six months,

facts.text: Calcutta High Court reversed Special Bench, restored Small Causes decree.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta, the decree passed by the -Special Bench was reversed and the decree passed by the companyrt of first instance was restored.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate of fitness under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution this appeal is preferred by the appellant against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Acceptance of rent after tenancy expiry does not create tenant holding over under s.116 TPA due to rent control.

anchor.surface_text: Does the acceptance of the amounts paid by the appellant companyfer upon him the right of a tenant holding over within the meaning of s. 116 of the Transfer of Property Act? ... acceptance of rent from the tenant by the landlord after the expiration or determination of the companytractual tenancy will number afford ground for holding that the landlord has assented to a new companytractual tenancy.

facts.text: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, 1950 s.12 protects tenants whose tenancies expired.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 of the West Bengal Premises Rent Control Act, 1950, expressly protects a tenant whose lease has expired.
With certificate of fitness under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution this appeal is preferred by the appellant against the order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rent control statutes grant statutory immunity; acceptance is compelled by law, not voluntary assent creating new tenancy under s.116 TPA; supported by precedents like Kai Khushroo

holdings.text: acceptance of the amounts from him which were equivalent to rent after the contractual tenancy had expired or which were fixed as standard rent did not amount to acceptance of rent from a lessee within the meaning of s. 116, Transfer of Property Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments are under statutory protection, not contractual lease renewal; s.116 requires voluntary assent absent in rent control compulsion

anchor.surface_text: Failure to take action which was consequent upon a statutory prohibition imposed upon the courts and not the result of any voluntary conduct on the part of the appellant did not also amount to otherwise assenting to the lessee continuing in possession.

The High Court was in our judgment right in holding that by merely accepting rent from the appellant and by failing to take action against him, the appellant did number acquire the rights of a tenant holding over.
